questions.text: Which of the virus after infection becomes dormant in dorsal root ganglia?
questions.solution:
• Varicella-zoster is one of the most common viral infections Of the peripheral nervous system.
  • A latent infection persists within neurons of sensory ganglia.
  • If the virus is reactivated, sometimes many years later, it may be transported along the sensory nerves to the skin.
  • Here it infects keratinocytes, leading to a painful, vesicular skin eruption in a distribution that follows sensory dermatomes (shingles).
  • Most common is the involvement of thoracic or trigeminal nerve dermatomes.
  • Decreased cell-mediated immunity is suspected to play a role.
  • Affected ganglia show neuronal death
  • Microscopy:-
    • Abundant mononuclear inflammatory cell infiltrates
    • Focal necrosis
    • Hemorrhage
  • Peripheral nerves show degeneration of the axons that belong to the dead sensory neurons.
  • Focal destruction of the large motor neurons of the anterior horns or cranial nerve motor nuclei may be seen at the corresponding levels.
  • Intranuclear inclusions generally are not found in the peripheral nervous system

Key Takeaways:

  • Varicella-zoster virus: Dormant in dorsal root ganglia.
  • Reactivation: Causes shingles (dermatomal rash).
  • Common sites: Thoracic, trigeminal dermatomes.
  • Trigger: Low immunity.
  • Histology: Neuronal death, axonal degeneration, mononuclear infiltrates.

questions.text: Type II muscle fibre atrophy with glucocorticoid excess is seen in which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Type II fibre atrophy with sparing of type I fibers is seen with prolonged corticosteroid therapy or disuse.

  • The most common type of myopathy induced by the drug is due to glucocorticoids.
  • Around 60% of Cushing syndrome patients have muscle weakness.
  • Type II fibers (glycolytic, fast twitch muscle fibers) are usually affected
  • In acute phase of the drug induced myopathy creatinine kinase and aldolase are elevated.

Key Takeaways: Type II fibre atrophy (fast-twitch) occurs in Cushing's syndrome or glucocorticoid excess, with muscle weakness in ~60% of cases. Acute phase shows elevated CK and aldolase.

choices.text: Deposition of C5b9 within capillary beds
Anti Mi2 & Anti So1 antibodies test

questions.solution:
• Dermatomyositis is a systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with proximal muscle weakness and skin changes
  • Damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.
  • Biopsies of muscle and skin may show deposition of the complement membrane attack complex (C5b-9) within capillary beds. (Choice C)
  • Autoantibodies detected in the circulation:- (choice D)
    • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodelling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash
    • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as "mechanic's hands."
    • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.
  • Muscle biopsies à infiltrates of mononuclear inflammatory cells in the perimysial connective tissue and around blood vessels.
    • Sometimes there is a distinctive pattern in which myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles-PERIFASCICULAR ATROPHY. (Choice B)
    • Segmental fibre necrosis and regeneration
  • Clinical Features à Muscle weakness is slow in onset, symmetric, and often accompanied by myalgias. It typically affects the proximal muscles first. (Choice A)
    As a result, tasks such as getting up from a chair and climbing stairs becomes extremely difficult.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dermatomyositis affects proximal muscles first (not distal).
  • Key findings: perifascicular atrophy, C5b-9 deposition in capillaries, and autoantibodies (Anti-Mi2, Anti-Jo1).
  • Symptoms: Symmetric muscle weakness, skin changes, and myalgias.

questions.text: The following clinical image of this patient show particular discoloration of upper eyelids with periorbital edema. She complains of difficulties in getting up from chair and climbing chairs. This patient has dusky red patches over knuckles, elbows and knees. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Dermatomyositis is a systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with proximal muscle weakness and skin changes
  • Damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.
  • Biopsies of muscle and skin may show deposition of the complement membrane attack complex (C5b-9) within capillary beds.
  • Autoantibodies detected in the circulation:-
    • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodelling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash
    • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as "mechanic's hands."
    • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.
  • Muscle biopsies à infiltrates of mononuclear inflammatory cells in the perimysial connective tissue and around blood vessels.
    • Sometimes there is a distinctive pattern in which myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles-PERIFASCICULAR ATROPHY.
    • Segmental fibre necrosis and regeneration
  • Clinical Features à Muscle weakness is slow in onset, symmetric, and often accompanied by myalgias. It typically affects the proximal muscles first.
    • As a result, tasks such as getting up from a chair and climbing stairs becomes extremely difficult.
    • The most characteristic rashes are a lilac-coloured discoloration of the upper eyelids (heliotrope rash) associated with periorbital edema (shown in the image) and a scaling erythematous eruption or dusky red patches over the knuckles, elbows, and knees (Gottron papules).
    • Dysphagia
    • 10% of patients have interstitial lung disease
    • Cardiac involvement is common, but rarely leads to cardiac failure

Key Takeaways: Dermatomyositis characterized by proximal muscle weakness and distinctive skin changes, such as the heliotrope rash (lilac discoloration of the eyelids) and Gottron papules (dusky red patches on knuckles, elbows, and knees). Muscle weakness often affects the proximal muscles, making tasks like rising from a chair difficult. Autoantibodies like Anti-Mi2 and Anti-Jo1 are commonly detected, and muscle biopsies show inflammatory infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy.

questions.text: 63 years old male with the diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma comes to the medicine clinic with proximal muscle weakness. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block Ach release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel.
  • Rapid repetitive stimulation increases muscle response.
  • Muscle strength is augmented after a few seconds of muscle activity.
  • Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities.
  • In about half of cases there is an underlying malignancy, most often neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung.
  • Symptoms may precede the diagnosis of cancer, sometimes by years
  • The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells.
  • Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease.
  • Treatment àdrugs that increase Ach release by depolarizing synaptic membranes and immunosuppressive agents, such as those used to treat myasthenia gravis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS): Autoimmune disorder blocking Ach release by inhibiting presynaptic calcium channels.
  • Muscle weakness: Primarily affects extremities; strength improves with rapid repetitive stimulation.
  • Associated with cancer: Often linked to neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung, with symptoms sometimes preceding the cancer diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Includes drugs that enhance Ach release and immunosuppressive agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is a form of compressive neuropathy in which plantar nerve is trapped between metatarsal heads?
questions.solution:
COMPRESSION NEUROPATHY (entrapment neuropathy) → occurs when a peripheral nerve is chronically subjected to increased pressure, often within an anatomic compartment.

Examples:-

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome → compression of the median nerve at the level of the wrist within the compartment delimited by the transverse carpal ligament.
    • Women > men
    • Association with many conditions including tissue edema, pregnancy, inflammatory arthritis, hypothyroidism, amyloidosis (especially related to β2-microglobulin Deposition in individuals on renal dialysis), acromegaly, diabetes mellitus, and excessive repetitive motions of the wrist.
    • Symptoms → numbness and paraesthesia of the tips of the thumb and first two digits.
  • Ulnar nerve at the level of the elbow
  • the peroneal nerve at the level of the knee
  • The radial nerve in the upper arm; this occurs from sleeping with the arm in an awkward position ("Saturday night palsy").
  • In the foot, affecting the interdigital nerve at intermetatarsal sites. This problem, which occurs more often in women than in men, leads to foot pain (metatarsalgia) and is associated with a histologic lesion called a MORTON NEUROMA, which is marked by perineural fibrosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Morton Neuroma: A compressive neuropathy where the plantar nerve is trapped between metatarsal heads.
  • Symptoms: Foot pain (metatarsalgia), more common in women.
  • Histology: Perineural fibrosis.

choices.text: Peroneal nerve at the level of knee
Radial nerve at the level of upper arm
Ulnar nerve at the level of elbow
Plantar nerve at the level of intermetatarsal site

questions.text: In Saturday night palsy, injured nerve is?
questions.solution:
COMPRESSION NEUROPATHY (entrapment neuropathy) → occurs when a peripheral nerve is chronically subjected to increased pressure, often within an anatomic compartment.

The radial nerve in the upper arm; this occurs from sleeping with the arm in an awkward position ("Saturday night palsy").

Key Takeaways: Saturday night palsy: Compression of the radial nerve in the upper arm due to prolonged pressure (e.g., awkward sleeping position).

questions.text: A 49 years old female presents with bilateral proximal muscle weakness. Muscle biopsy shows endomysial lymphocytic inflammation, skeletal muscle fibers degeneration and regeneration. The probable diagnosis for this patient is?
questions.solution:
Polymyositis is an adult-onset inflammatory myopathy that shares myalgia and weakness with dermatomyositis but lacks its distinctive cutaneous features.

Morphology:-

  • Mononuclear(lymphocytic) inflammatory cell infiltrates are present, but in contrast to dermatomyositis, these are usually ENDOMYSIAL in location.
  • Myofibers with otherwise normal morphology appear to be invaded by mononuclear inflammatory cells, predominantly CD8+ T
  • Degenerating necrotic, regenerating, and atrophic myofibers are typically found in a random or patchy distribution.
  • The perifascicular pattern of atrophy that is characteristic of dermatomyositis is absent

Key Takeaways:

  • Polymyositis: Adult-onset inflammatory myopathy with bilateral proximal muscle weakness.
  • Muscle biopsy: Endomysial inflammation, CD8+ T-cell infiltrates, and patchy myofiber degeneration/regeneration.
  • No skin features (unlike dermatomyositis).

choices.text: Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome is caused by antibodies to postsynaptic calcium channels and presynaptic Ach receptors.
Gullain barre syndrome is the major acute acquired demyelinating peripheral neuropathy
Triton tumor has features of rhabdomyoblastic morphology with neurofibroma
Polymyositis is most commonly seen in children and caused by CD4+T cells

questions.text: Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
• Polymyositis is an adult-onset inflammatory myopathy that shares myalgia and weakness with dermatomyositis but lacks its distinctive cutaneous features.
    • Mononuclear(lymphocytic - predominantly CD8+ T cells) inflammatory cell infiltrates are present, ENDOMYSIAL in location. (Choice D)
  • Triton tumor has features of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor along with rhabdomyoblastic (Choice C)
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome is the major acute and chronic acquired demyelinating peripheral neuropathies. (Choice B)
  • Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome presents with weakness in the extremities that improves with repetitive stimulation and is often a paraneoplastic disorder associated with lung cancer. (Choice A)

questions.text: Which of the following condition is consistent with sensory neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Diabetes is the most common cause of peripheral neuropathy.

  • The prevalence :- 50% of patients with diabetes overall and up to 80% of those who have had the disease for more than 15 years have clinical evidence of peripheral neuropathy.
  • Patients with both type 1 and type 2 diabetes are affected
  • The most common Pattern of diabetes-related peripheral neuropathy → Ascending distal symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy.
  • In individuals with a distal symmetric sensorimotor neuropathy, the predominant pathologic finding is an AXONAL NEUROPATHY.
  • Nerve biopsies → reduced numbers of axons.
  • Axonal damage, marked by degenerating myelin sheaths and regenerative axonal clusters, may be present.
  • Endoneurial arterioles show thickening, hyalinization, and intense periodic acid-Schiff positivity of their walls and extensive reduplication of basement membranes

Key Takeaways:

  • Diabetic neuropathy is the most common cause of sensory neuropathy, affecting 50-80% of diabetics.
  • Most common type: Ascending distal symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy due to axonal neuropathy.
  • Pathology: Axonal damage, reduced axons, and vascular changes in endoneurial arterioles.
